results.title: Magic lantern set effects slide (Man and lions)
results.brief_description: Magic lantern set effects slide with wooden frame. By sliding the effects slide, a man fights between two lions set against a black background. Made by Lawler, 161 Strand, London. ‘91’ written in pencil on wooden frame. Cream tape has been adhered to the edge of the sliding section.

results.title: Shape description. Part 2
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Mechanical Drawing”.
This film is designed as a sequel to “Shape description part 1” which presented the theory of orthographic projection. In part 2, the step-by-step procedure of constructing a drawing is demonstrated, and reasons for each step are explained.

results.title: Shop procedures
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Mechanical Drawing”.
This film shows how finished drawings are used as detailed instructions in every step of manufacturing. From the drafting room the drawings are seen going to the blue-printing machine to the reproduced by the dozens or hundreds and distributed to all those workmen who will have a part in making the finished project, The film then shows many of these workmen at their jobs using blueprints in the pattern-making assembly shop, the foundry, the forging shop, and the assembly room.

results.title: Auxiliary views. Pt. 1
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Mechanical Drawing”.
Begins by showing that the three principal views do not represent the true surface of an object that has one or more slanting faces. This condition is shown to require projection of the slanting surface on a plane which is parallel to it and is not one of the principle planes. This auxiliary projection is explained and defined. No other credits available.

results.title: Size description
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Mechanical Drawing”.
This film presents the reasons why uniformity in dimensioning practices is essential, and explains that this uniformity depends on observance of certain standards in: 1. use of symbols; 2. choice of dimensions; 3. location of dimensions. The first step in learning this common language consists in extension lines, dimension lines, arrow heads, figures, notes, finish marks etc.

results.title: Mechanical Drawing
results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

results.title: Shape description. Part 1
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Mechanical Drawing”.
The film begins by demonstrating that the only accurate method of telling others exactly how to build an object is to make several drawings showing how the object looks from different points of view. The film then describes orthographic projection, utilising animated diagrams and animated models to provide unusual three-dimensional effects.

results.title: Sections
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Mechanical Drawing”

Some objects have important interior details which may show as a confused mass of dotted lines on the regular exterior views. The remedy for this is the sectional view, formed by the imaginary cutting away of part of the object to reveal interior details.

results.title: Language of drawing
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Mechanical Drawing”.
This film attempts to provide a sensible and acceptable answer to the question: “Why study mechanical drawing?” and to stimulate the beginning of students’ interest in the subject.

results.title: Bulk buy beef
results.creator_credit: Meat and Livestock Australia and Kingcroft Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Meat makes the meal”.
This film clearly illustrates the variety of meat cuts available to the purchasers of bulk beef. The preparation of a side of beef from commercial cuts to domestic cuts to suit the preference of the purchaser is demonstrated. The advantages of home freezer use are emphasised.
